section.title: Location-Speakers
section.para: Beja is a closely related group of language varieties and dialects spoken in the Red Sea coastal and hill regions in Sudan, Eritrea, and Egypt by more than a million individuals. The Northern-most representative of Beja is documented here, that of the Bishari in Aswan and Sudan, studied by Herma Almkvist (1881) in one of the earliest monographs dedicated to a variety of Beja.

biblioset.title: Die Bischari-Sprache Tu:-Bed'a:wiye in Nordost-Afrika (beschreibend und vergleichenddargestellet)

section.title: Morphosyntactic Properties
section.para: Beja-Bishari paradigms employ the following property-value dimenstions

listitem.para: Bishari, like the other varieties of Beja makes more PNG distinctions than are found in the Cushitic-Omotic PNG Pattern

Although Beja has the same property-value features as the rest of Cushitic (viz., sg/pl, p1/p2/p3, m/f), it has a more extensive (and more archaic) set of gender distinctions:
number person gender
sg p1 "⊤"
sg p2 "m"
sg p2 "f"
sg p3 m
sg p3 m
sg p3 f
pl p1 "⊤"
pl p2 "m"
pl p2 "f"
pl p3 "m"
pl p3 "f"
I.e., where gender is distinguished not only in the third-person singular, but also in the third-person plural, and in the second-person singular and plural,.
